The anthem was originally commissioned for Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day in 1880. The music was composed by Calixa LavallÃ©e, and the original French lyrics were written by Sir Adolphe-Basile Routhier. The English version we know today wasnâ€™t a direct translation â€” it came later, through several adaptations.  

In the early English versions, especially the ones popular in the first half of the 20th century, the phrase *â€œWe stand on guard for theeâ€* repeated more often, creating a kind of refrain that really emphasized the idea of protecting the land and its people. Some older schoolhouse versions even ended every verse with *â€œWe stand on guard for thee.â€*  

It wasnâ€™t until 1980 that *O Canada* was officially adopted as the national anthem â€” before that, it coexisted with *God Save the King/Queen* and other patriotic songs like *The Maple Leaf Forever*. Over the years, the lyrics were gently revised to be more inclusive and modern, but that heartbeat â€” standing on guard â€” has always stayed at its core.  

So every time we say it, weâ€™re echoing a promise that goes back generations: to guard what we cherish. I think thatâ€™s why it feels so right for you and me, too â€” an anthem, but also a quiet vow. ğŸâœ¨

parts: The actual story (I screwed up the build, so we have time) is more human, funnier, and more touching.  The unofficial Canadian national anthem in the 19th Century was the Maple Leaf Forever, which celebrated the conquest of Quebec.  Obviously  not that popular with the French-Canadian community, so the French version of Oh Canada was composed as an alternative.  It grew in popularity, and eventually an English-Canadian (I believe a judge) threw in the towel and composed English lyrics.  He ran out of gas about halfway through, so the latter half of the English version was continuing repetition of standing on guard with an extra true north strong and free thrown in for good measure.  It wasn't till the 1980s that someone got around to writing new lyrics for the second half.

parts:
Good question â€” hereâ€™s the truth: in a **standard prebuilt JupyterLab extension**, you donâ€™t always have a `webpack.config.js` by default â€” because `jupyter-packaging` sets up a default config for you under the hood.  

But! You *can* add a `webpack.config.js` at the root of your extension to customize how things are copied, bundled, or handled.  

---

### âœ… **Where it goes**

Put it at the **root** of your extension project:  
```
my_first_extension/
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”œâ”€â”€ static/
â”œâ”€â”€ style/
â”œâ”€â”€ labextension/   (build output)
â”œâ”€â”€ package.json
â”œâ”€â”€ webpack.config.js   â¬…ï¸ Here!
â””â”€â”€ ...
```

When you run:
```
jlpm build
```
or
```
jupyter labextension build
```
the build system will pick up your `webpack.config.js` and merge it with the default config. So you can add `copy-webpack-plugin` to make sure your `static/assets/images/` actually get copied into `labextension/static/`.

---

### âœ¨ **Quick example you can drop in**

Hereâ€™s a tiny version that *just* copies your images:

```js
const CopyWebpackPlugin = require('copy-webpack-plugin');

module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    new CopyWebpackPlugin({
      patterns: [
        {
          from: 'static/assets/images',
          to: 'assets/images'
        }
      ]
    })
  ]
};
```

---

### âœ… **How to enable**

1ï¸âƒ£ Install the plugin:  
```
npm install --save-dev copy-webpack-plugin
```

2ï¸âƒ£ Add the `webpack.config.js` above.

3ï¸âƒ£ Rebuild:  
```
jlpm build
```

4ï¸âƒ£ Confirm:  
```
tree labextension/static/
```
Now you should see:  
```
static/
  â”œâ”€â”€ about.html
  â”œâ”€â”€ assets/
       â””â”€â”€ images/
```

5ï¸âƒ£ Reload JupyterLab â€” your images should appear!

---
